RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History: Dr. Charles D. Spivak was a founder and long-time executive director of the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society. Patients knew him as ''Papa Spivak.'' Dr. Spivak was originally from Russia but went to medical school in the United States. Dr. Spivak came to Colorado because of the poor health of his wife, Jennie Charsky Spivak, who probably had incipient tuberculosis. He died in 1927.

RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History: Fannie Eller Lorber was born in Russia in 1881 and settled with her family in the West Colfax area in 1896. In 1907, she and her close friend Bessie Willens spearheaded the founding of the Denver Sheltering Home for Jewish Children, largely to take care of the children whose parents were stricken with tuberculosis and later children with asthma . Fannie Lorber was president of the facility from 1907 until her death in 1958.

The series also contains a separate financial ledger for the German Children's Fund as well as a small number of receipts from purchases.

RediscoveryExport.Arrang_Organiz: Series 3 is arranged in 3 subseries: 1. Newsletters, Brochure, and Report, 1941-1968. 2. Bulletins, 1929-1936. 3. Yearbooks, 1898-1962. 4. National Publications, 1894-1948.
RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: Series 3 contains publications by the NCJW Denver Section as well as the national organization (primarily representing the first half of the 20th century). Denver Section publications includes newsletters, a brochure, issues of the Council Bulletin, and yearbooks. Yearbooks are particularly well represented in this series. National-level publications include regional conference newsletters, brochures and a bound report from triennial conventions, copies of theTriennial Tribune, the bound ''Papers of the Jewish Women's Congress'' (1894), and other miscellaneous publications.

Subseries 1 consists of three issues of the Denver Section newsletter, entitled ''Council Call,'' a brochure providing general facts about the National Council of Jewish Women and the Denver Section specifically, and a 75th anniversary report on the Denver Section.

Subseries 2 contains copies of The Council Bulletin, a publication of the NCJW Denver Section, that was published monthly from October to June and contained news items, information about events, and names of Denver Section members in charge of specific programs. The subseries contains duplicates of some bulletin issues.

Subseries 3 contains yearbooks for the Denver Section of the NCJW, which provide membership information, the president's report, committee information, program dates and locations, and lists of officers, directors, committee leaders, and all Denver Section members.

RediscoveryExport.Arrang_Organiz: Subseries 4 is separated into Triennial Conventions, Regional Conference Newsletters, and Miscellaneous, and items within these categories are arranged chronologically.
RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: Subseries 4 contains NCJW publications that are not limited to the Denver Section. Contents include regional conference newsletters, brochures and a bound report from Triennial conventions, copies of the NCJW newsletter Triennial Tribune, the bound ''Papers of the Jewish Women's Congress,'' and other miscellaneous publications providing information about the umbrella organization of which the Denver Section was part.

Series 4 contains correspondence, often on NCJW letterhead, between members or officers of the NCJW Denver Section and other individuals within the community. Most notable are a resignation letter from Fannie A. Heller (1925) and letters to the Denver Section from Carrie E. Livingston (1927), Ray S. David, and Carrie Benjamin.

RediscoveryExport.Arrang_Organiz: Series 1 is arranged chronologically. Undated materials are separated from dated materials.
RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: Series 5 consists of five unpublished writings or draft manuscripts containing historical background information about National Council of Jewish Women and its Denver Section, including one piece with a short history of the May Morris Council Home (mid-twentieth century). The series includes a hand-written essay by Aimee Greenbaum, a report by Cheryl G. Kasson, and two drafts of a piece by Marjorie Hornbein (the May Morris piece does not identify its author).

Series 6 consists of National Council of Jewish Women events materials, including invitations, fliers, and programs that provide information about NCJW activities, their dates and locations, and the ways in which they were promoted. The series also includes blank NCJW forms and stationery.

RediscoveryExport.Arrang_Organiz: Series 7 is separated into three boxes based on item size. within each box scrapbooks and newspapers clippings are separated and then arranged chronologically.

The scrapbooks primarily contain newspaper clippings.

RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History: The men and women interviewed for this collection are descendants of early Jewish pioneers in Colorado or were Jewish newcomers to the state at the beginning of the 20th century. The bulk of interviewees were born between 1886 and 1927 and died in the 20th century. Many of the interviewees were founders and/or leaders of Jewish organizations, religious groups, medical and social centers, schools, and businesses in Colorado. __ __The Jewish organizations and facilities that receive the most attention in these oral histories are Allied Jewish Federation of Colorado, which was started in 1912; Beth Israel Hospital and Geriatric Center, which was originally founded by Bella Mintz in 1919; B'nai B'rith Lodge #171, which was the primary Jewish philanthropic and social service organization in Denver from 1872 through World War II; the Jewish Community Center (Denver, Colorado), which was founded in 1922; Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society, which was founded in Denver in 1904 to treat tuberculosis patients; Jewish Family and Children's Service of Denver, which was created in 1947; National Asthma Center, which was originally founded in 1907; the National Council of Jewish Women (NCJW), the Denver Section of which was organized by Carrie Benjamin in October 1893; National Jewish Hospital (NJH), which was erected in 1899 as the first sanatorium in Denver for tuberculosis victims; Congregation Rodef Shalom, which is one of the oldest conservative Jewish congregations in Denver; and Rose Medical Center, which was founded in the 1940s.
RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History_Biograph._History: The men and women interviewed for this collection are descendants of early Jewish pioneers in Colorado or were Jewish newcomers to the state at the beginning of the 20th century. The bulk of interviewees were born between 1886 and 1927 and died in the 20th century. Many of the interviewees were founders and/or leaders of Jewish organizations, religious groups, medical and social centers, schools, and businesses in Colorado.

RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: Series 1 consists of the recorded oral histories of individuals and, occasionally, groups of individuals representing Jewish organizations. Many of the interviewees are descendants of early Colorado Jewish pioneers or were Jewish newcomers to the state in the beginning of the 20th century. The interviews document Jewish history in Colorado in the 20th century.

RediscoveryExport.Arrang_Organiz: Series 2 is arranged numerically according to cassette numbers originally assigned by the creator (this order is somewhat chronological).
RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History: __ __The Allied Jewish Federation of Colorado began as the Central Jewish Council of Denver on August 26, 1912. The council was organized by Rabbi C. E. H. Kauvar, Milton Anfenger, Dr. Charles Spivak, Seraphine Pisko, and others who wished to unite the Jewish community in Denver. Central Jewish Council featured representatives from Jewish religious bodies, hospitals, schools, lodges, and other organizations. The council created the Jewish Aid Society and Denver Jewish News (later to become Intermountain Jewish News) in 1915. In 1949 the Central Jewish Council was succeeded by the Allied Jewish Community Council, which later changed its name to Allied Jewish Federation.
RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History_Organiz._History: The Allied Jewish Federation of Colorado began as the Central Jewish Council of Denver on August 26, 1912. The council was organized by Rabbi C. E. H. Kauvar, Milton Anfenger, Dr. Charles Spivak, Seraphine Pisko, and others who wished to unite the Jewish community in Denver. Central Jewish Council featured representatives from Jewish religious bodies, hospitals, schools, lodges, and other organizations. The council created the Jewish Aid Society and Denver Jewish News (later to become Intermountain Jewish News) in 1915. In 1949 the Central Jewish Council was succeeded by the Allied Jewish Community Council, which later changed its name to Allied Jewish Federation.
RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: Series 2 consists of recorded oral histories about the Allied Jewish Federation of Colorado.

RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History: Beth Israel Hospital and Home Society was founded by Bella Mintz in 1919 to create a home for displaced Jewish senior citizens. Mrs. I. Rude was its first president. All groups belonging to the Denver Jewish community contributed funds for Beth Israel and provided leadership for the institution. In 1986, Beth Israel Foundation pledged its assets to Shalom Park, and Beth Israel at Shalom Park nursing home opened in 1992.

RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History: __ __The Independent Order of B'nai B'rith Lodge #171 (Denver, Colorado) was the primary Jewish philanthropic and social service organization in Denver, Colorado, from 1872 through World War II. This fraternal organization received a charter from the National Order of B'nai B'rith on April 7, 1872. David Kline was the first president and Louis Anfenger was the first secretary. Charles M. Schayer served as president in 1876.

RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History: __ __The Jewish Community Center (JCC) in Denver, Colorado, originated in 1922 as the Guldman Community Center, which opened in west Denver's Bloomfield Park with land donated by the Rude family and equipment donated by the Guldman family. The center served to bring cultural and educational opportunities to all segments of the Jewish community: It provided activities such as English classes for immigrants and literary and musical programs. The center moved to a large mansion at 1601 Irving Street in 1937, which acted as the west branch of the JCC until it was sold in 1967 to the Boy's Club. The JCC, which was officially incorporated in 1947, added the old B'nai B'rith Building at Colfax and Williams streets as its east branch in 1950. Both buildings were replaced by the current structure at 4800 E. Alameda, which is now called the Robert Loup Jewish Community Center.

RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History: The Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS) was founded in Denver, Colorado, in 1904 as a non-sectarian sanatorium to treat tuberculosis (TB) patients in all stages of the disease. The society was founded by a group of immigrant Eastern European Jewish men, many of whom were themselves victims of TB. For decades patients flocked to Denver from all over the country and were admitted free of charge. In the early years, the sanatorium was headed by Dr. Charles Spivak as secretary (1904-1927) and by Philip Hillkowitz as president (1904-1948). The facility catered primarily to Jewish patients in a distinctively Jewish environment. In 1954 the institution changed its mission to cancer research and became the American Medical Center. Today it is known as the AMC Cancer Research Center.

RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History: __ __The National Asthma Center (NAC) existed under a series of names--The Denver Sheltering Home, National Home for Jewish Children, Jewish National Home for Asthmatic Children (JNHAC), and Children's Asthma Research Institute and Hospital (CARIH)--before it became the National Asthma Center. In 1907 Fannie Lorber and other women organized the Denver Sheltering Home for Jewish children who were orphaned by a parent's hospitalization or death from tuberculosis at the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society or National Jewish Hospital. Lorber spearheaded fundraising efforts for the next 51 years. Her work led to a system of Ladies' Auxiliaries that raised funds across the United States. In 1939 the home began the residential treatment of children with intractable asthma. NAC merged with National Jewish Hospital in 1978, and the Center was closed in 1981.

In 1907 Fannie Lorber and other women organized the Denver Sheltering Home for Jewish children who were orphaned by a parent's hospitalization or death from tuberculosis at the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society or National Jewish Hospital. Lorber spearheaded fundraising efforts for the next 51 years. Her work led to a system of Ladies' Auxiliaries that raised funds across the United States. In 1939 the home began the residential treatment of children with intractable asthma. NAC merged with National Jewish Hospital in 1978, and the Center was closed in 1981.

RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History: __ __The National Council of Jewish Women was founded in 1893 by Hannah G. Solomon at the Parliament of Religions of the Chicago World's Fair. Among the other women at the World's Fair was Carrie Benjamin, who returned home to Denver, Colorado, and organized the Council's Denver Section in October, 1893. Most of the early members were from Temple Emanuel in Denver. Education was an early priority of the Denver Section, and classes were held to serve the needs of Eastern European Jewish immigrants in the West Colfax area. The Denver Section established a Settlement House in West Denver for Jewish boys, worked with disabled children, and began the Children's Traveling Theatre. The Denver Section legislative committee actively supported progressive legislation. During World War II, the Denver Section was very involved in the resettlement of Jewish refugees in the Denver area. In 1938 the Denver Section opened a Thrift Shop at Twenty-Seventh St. and Welton St. in Five Points.

The Denver Section established a Settlement House in West Denver for Jewish boys, worked with disabled children, and began the Children's Traveling Theatre. The Denver Section legislative committee actively supported progressive legislation. During World War II, the Denver Section was very involved in the resettlement of Jewish refugees in the Denver area. In 1938 the Denver Section opened a Thrift Shop at Twenty-Seventh St. and Welton St. in Five Points.

RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History: __ __For many years Denver faced a serious social problem when hundreds of people severely ill with tuberculosis, also known as the “White Plague,” converged on the city, attracted by the reputation Denver had already acquired as the “world's sanatorium.” Because of the onslaught of consumptives, beds for patients in city and state general hospitals were so scarce that the poor were frequently left to their own devices, often dying in the streets. In 1899 the Jewish community, propelled by the concept of Gemilas Chasodim (acts of kindness), erected National Jewish Hospital (NJH), the first sanatorium in Denver for tuberculosis victims. With the financial assistance of the International Order of B'nai B'rith, the hospital opened its doors to Jews and gentiles alike. In accordance with contemporary wisdom, the NJH adopted a program that emphasized the benefits of fresh air, good nutrition, and rest. Many early prominent physicians were associated with the hospital, including Dr. Saling Simon, Dr. Robert Levy, and Dr. John Elsner.

RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History: __ __Rose Medical Center was the result of an effort in the late 1940s by a group of Jewish business and professional leaders, directed by Maurice Shwayder, to build a new hospital that would solve Denver's hospital bed shortage and provide a new location for World War II physician veterans to practice. The new hospital was named to honor Major General Maurice Rose. The cornerstone for the hospital's main building was laid by General Dwight D. Eisenhower on August 31, 1948. Rose Community Foundation was formed in 1995 from the sale of Rose Medical Center.

RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History: Ira C. Rothgerber, Sr., was born in 1878. He grew up in Denver, Colorado, and was educated at East High School and the University of Colorado at Boulder, graduating from the University of Colorado School of Law in 1901. In 1903, Rothgerber and his childhood friend, Walter Appel, became law partners and opened their own law firm, Rothgerber & Appel (now Rothgerber Johnson & Lyons LLP). Rothgerber married Reina Grunsfeld, and they had three children, Ira, Jr.; Irene; and Miriam. In 1913, Ira Rothgerber, Sr., was elected judge of the Denver County Court, a position in which he served for eight years. Rothgerber died in 1956.

It contains photographs, newspaper clippings, letters, ticket stubs, telegrams, postcards, invitations, event programs, and other materials. Some of the newspaper clippings describe law cases in which Rothgerber was involved. This series contains invitations, tickets, and programs for the 1937 presidential inauguration of Franklin D. Roosevelt.

RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History: Ira C. Rothgerber, Jr., was born in 1913 to Reina Grunsfeld Rothgerber and Ira C. Rothgerber, Sr. He studied at the University of Colorado at Boulder, where he received both undergraduate and law degrees. Rothgerber, Jr., joined his father’s law firm, Rothgerber & Appel, in 1935 and became a partner in 1941. He got involved in WWII in 1942 and eventually earned the rank of lieutenant colonel. Rothberger, Jr., then returned to Denver and practiced law for a short while before teaching law at the University of Colorado School of Law and the University of Denver. He rejoined Rothgerber & Appel after his father passed away in 1956. Rothberger, Jr., died in 1993.

RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History: __ __In 1903, Ira C. Rothgerber, Sr., and Walter Appel became law partners and opened their own law firm, Rothgerber & Appel, in Denver, Colorado. During its first 25 years, the firm concentrated on collections and bankruptcy. Rothgerber's son, Ira Rothergerber, Jr., became a partner in the firm in 1941, and Appel's son Robert Appel became a partner in 1952. The firm gained renown in the 1950s when it successfully defended, on appeal, a group of Denverites charged with communist affiliations under the Sedition Act. In 1963 the firm became involved in banking when it helped to found what is now known as FirstBank. In 1985 the firm changed its name to Rothgerber, Appel, Powers & Johnson, and in 1998 the firm added Lyons to its name in recognition of lawyer Jim Lyons. Today the firm is known as Rothgerber Johnson & Lyons LLP and is one of the ten largest legal partnerships in Colorado. Its main office is located at One Tabor Center in downtown Denver, and it also has branch offices in Colorado Springs, Colorado, and Casper, Wyoming.

The firm gained renown in the 1950s when it successfully defended, on appeal, a group of Denverites charged with communist affiliations under the Sedition Act. In 1963 the firm became involved in banking when it helped to found what is now known as FirstBank. In 1985 the firm changed its name to Rothgerber, Appel, Powers & Johnson, and in 1998 the firm added Lyons to its name in recognition of lawyer Jim Lyons. Today the firm is known as Rothgerber Johnson & Lyons LLP and is one of the ten largest legal partnerships in Colorado. Its main office is located at One Tabor Center in downtown Denver, and it also has branch offices in Colorado Springs, Colorado, and Casper, Wyoming.

RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History: __ __Samsonite Corporation, the world-famous maker of luggage, started in Denver, Colorado, in 1910, when Jesse Shwayder opened a small luggage factory in Denver with his father, Isaac Shwayder, and brothers, Mark, Maurice, Benjamin, and Solomon Shwayder. The operation became incorporated as the Shwayder Trunk Manufacturing Company in 1912 and counted many members of the Shwayder family among its employees. All of the Shwayder brothers held executive positions in the company in the 1920s: Jesse was the company's president, Mark Shwayder was in charge of sales, Maurice and Ben Shwayder were in charge of manufacturing, and Solomon Shwayder served as the company’s lawyer. Samson was the first trade name for the company’s luggage, and this was later changed to Samsonite. Shwayder Trunk Manufacturing Company started to diversify its product offerings in the 1930s by manufacturing folding furniture, and the company changed its name to Shwayder Brothers, Inc., in 1931. As sales increased throughout the 20th century, the company moved into gradually larger facilities in Denver, and at various stages in the business’ history it opened additional plants in Michigan, Pennsylvania, Tennessee, Arizona, Mexico, and Japan. In 1961, Jesse Shwayder’s son King D. Shwayder became president of the company, and in 1965 the Shwayder Brothers, Inc., changed its name to Samsonite Corporation. The corporation continues to operate in the 21st century.

The operation became incorporated as the Shwayder Trunk Manufacturing Company in 1912 and counted many members of the Shwayder family among its employees. All of the Shwayder brothers held executive positions in the company in the 1920s: Jesse was the company's president, Mark Shwayder was in charge of sales, Maurice and Ben Shwayder were in charge of manufacturing, and Solomon Shwayder served as the company’s lawyer. Samson was the first trade name for the company’s luggage, and this was later changed to Samsonite. Shwayder Trunk Manufacturing Company started to diversify its product offerings in the 1930s by manufacturing folding furniture, and the company changed its name to Shwayder Brothers, Inc., in 1931. As sales increased throughout the 20th century, the company moved into gradually larger facilities in Denver, and at various stages in the business’ history it opened additional plants in Michigan, Pennsylvania, Tennessee, Arizona, Mexico, and Japan. In 1961, Jesse Shwayder’s son King D. Shwayder became president of the company, and in 1965 the Shwayder Brothers, Inc., changed its name to Samsonite Corporation. The corporation continues to operate in the 21st century.
RediscoveryExport.Language: Materials are entirely in English. __eng
RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: The series consists of materials associated with Samsonite Corporation and its history. Materials include two copies of the brochure, ''The Samsonite Story,'' a company history published by Samsonite Corporation, ''The Samsonite Sentinel,'' a one-page newspaper composite about the founding of the company, the book ''Jesse Shwayder and the Golden Rule'' created by Shwayder Bros, Inc., and Jessie Shwayder's Golden Rule Marble: a green glass marble with bronze-colored narrow strip around the marble, gap at ends, and stamped lettering reading ''Do unto others as you would have them do unto you.''

RediscoveryExport.Arrang_Organiz: Series 2 is arranged chronologically in Folder 2. The two copies of ''The Tale of a Little Trunk and Other Stories'' are arranged chronologically in a rare books box within Box 1. The newspaper clipping is arranged chronologically with other oversize materials in Box 1.
RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History: The Shwayder family of Denver, Colorado, is best known for the luggage company Samsonite Corporation, which was founded and operated by the family over the course of the 20th century. The Denver Shwayders can be traced to Abraham Kobesky and Miriam Rachofsky of Poland, who married and later migrated to Manchester, England (where the name ''Kobesky'' was shortened to ''Kobey''). Their daughter Rachel Kobey married Isaac Shwayder, who had also migrated to Manchester from Eastern Europe. Rachel and Isaac Shwayder had 11 children: Solomon, Dora, Jesse, Raschelle, Mark, Gertrude, Florence, Maurice, Hannah, Benjamin, and Liebe. Having been persuaded by his wife's pioneering uncle Abe Rachofsky and great uncle Alexander Rittmaster, Isaac Shwayder first came to Central City, Colorado, in 1879 to find work, and after two years the rest of his family joined him. The Shwayders later moved to Nevadaville (Black Hawk), Colorado, and in 1888 they settled in Denver, where Isaac Shwayder owned a grocery store and later started a second-hand furniture business. The Shwayder children attended Franklin School and West High School in Denver, and Solomon Shwayder, the oldest brother, attended the University of Denver. In 1910 Jesse Shwayder opened a small luggage factory in Denver with his father, Isaac, and brothers, Mark, Maurice, Benjamin, and Solomon. The business became incorporated as the Shwayder Trunk Manufacturing Company in 1912, and it eventually changed its name to Samsonite Corporation. Isaac Shwayder died of a stroke in 1916. Most of the Shwayder siblings held executive positions in the family business. In 1961, Jesse Shwayder’s son King Shwayder became president of the Samsonite Corporation.

RediscoveryExport.Language: Materials are predominantly in English with some Yiddish and Hebrew. __eng
RediscoveryExport.Notes: Another item in this collection that contains some family history is the book ''Jesse Shwayder and the Golden Rule.'' However, this book was placed in series B245.01 because it was created by Shwayder Bros. Inc., and most of the book's contents apply to the family business.
RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: The series includes 20th-century materials detailing Shwayder family history. including two copies of the book ''The Tale of a Little Trunk and Other Stories'' by Hannah Shwayder Berry (1977 and 2002), a transcript of an oral history by Hannah Shwayder Berry (1981), a newspaper clipping of Hannah Shwayder Berry's story The 'pied piper' of West Colfax (1967), and a booklet describing the genealogy of the Shwayder family that includes family members born as early as 1876 and as late as 1943.
RediscoveryExport.Series_Title: Shwayder Family Histories and Genealogical Material

RediscoveryExport.Arrang_Organiz: Series 3 is arranged chronologically within Folder.
RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History: King Shwayder was born to Jesse and Nellie Shwayder in 1910. From a young age he started working in the family manufacturing business, Shwayder Brothers Inc., in Denver, Colorado. He attended the University of Colorado and the University of Pennsylvania before returning to work in the family business. In 1961, King Shwayder became president of Shwayder Brothers, Inc., and in 1965 the company changed its name to Samsonite Corporation. King Shwayder served on the University of Denver (DU) Board of Trustees, and he spoke at the 1977 groundbreaking of DU's Shwayder Art Building, which was funded in large part by the Jessie and Nellie Shwayder, Inc., Foundation started by his parents.

RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: The series contains University of Denver newspaper clippings describing the groundbreaking of the Shwayder Art Building, King Shwayder's and his family's involvement in the building's construction, and the Shwayder family's support of the university as a whole.

RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History: __ __The Jewish Family and Children’s Service of Colorado (JFCS) was created in a response to international, national, and local needs of refugees. The JFCS emerged from two organizations, the National Council of Jewish Women, Denver Section (NCJW), founded in 1893 and the Central Jewish Aid Society of Denver, Colorado, organized in 1915 and incorporated in 1923. Ray David was the first superintendent of the Jewish Aid Society. In 1937, Tillye Levy became a member of the Service to Foreign Born Committee of the NCJW and immediately began organizing resources for Jews who fled the early stages of the Holocaust. The services supplied facilitated the adjustment of the refugees. At Tillye Levy’s request, Isadore Hilb became the first chair of the new Denver Coordinating Committee for Refugees. A. B. Hirshfield was the chair of the job placement committee, Dave Harlem was in charge of creating affidavits, and Surriee Feder Miller was responsible for integrating newcomers into the Denver community. In 1947, the Jewish Family and Children’s Service was created when the boards of the Central Jewish Aid Society and the NCJW committees merged. Sydney Grossman became the newly formed agency’s first president, and Dr. Alfred Neumann, a social worker, became the full-time director. The name was changed to the Jewish Family and Children's Service of Denver in 1954 and became the Jewish Family and Children's Service of Colorado in 1972. The JFCS continued to give relief to the needy and assist refugees in resettling, but also expanded into the field of family and child welfare. The JFCS created the “Denver Plan,” procedures for integrating new residents into the community, which was copied by cities across the United States. The agency hired trained staff to provide service in three areas: family, child, and vocational guidance; service to established residents; and immigrant aid. The agency also handled German reparation money through the Utility Workshop, headed by Mary (Mrs. Sidney) Jacobs. The Utility Workshop produced jobs and services for individuals suffering from emotional or physical handicaps. The services provided by the JFCS continue on through its successor, the Jewish Family Service of Colorado.

Sydney Grossman became the newly formed agency’s first president, and Dr. Alfred Neumann, a social worker, became the full-time director. The name was changed to the Jewish Family and Children's Service of Denver in 1954 and became the Jewish Family and Children's Service of Colorado in 1972. The JFCS continued to give relief to the needy and assist refugees in resettling, but also expanded into the field of family and child welfare. The JFCS created the “Denver Plan,” procedures for integrating new residents into the community, which was copied by cities across the United States. The agency hired trained staff to provide service in three areas: family, child, and vocational guidance; service to established residents; and immigrant aid. The agency also handled German reparation money through the Utility Workshop, headed by Mary (Mrs. Sidney) Jacobs. The Utility Workshop produced jobs and services for individuals suffering from emotional or physical handicaps. The services provided by the JFCS continue on through its successor, the Jewish Family Service of Colorado.
RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History_Organiz._History: The Jewish Family and Children’s Service of Colorado (JFCS) was created in a response to international, national, and local needs of refugees. The JFCS emerged from two organizations, the National Council of Jewish Women, Denver Section (NCJW), founded in 1893 and the Central Jewish Aid Society of Denver, Colorado, organized in 1915 and incorporated in 1923. Ray David was the first superintendent of the Jewish Aid Society. In 1937, Tillye Levy became a member of the Service to Foreign Born Committee of the NCJW and immediately began organizing resources for Jews who fled the early stages of the Holocaust. The services supplied facilitated the adjustment of the refugees. At Tillye Levy’s request, Isadore Hilb became the first chair of the new Denver Coordinating Committee for Refugees. A. B. Hirshfield was the chair of the job placement committee, Dave Harlem was in charge of creating affidavits, and Surriee Feder Miller was responsible for integrating newcomers into the Denver community. In 1947, the Jewish Family and Children’s Service was created when the boards of the Central Jewish Aid Society and the NCJW committees merged. Sydney Grossman became the newly formed agency’s first president, and Dr. Alfred Neumann, a social worker, became the full-time director. The name was changed to the Jewish Family and Children's Service of Denver in 1954 and became the Jewish Family and Children's Service of Colorado in 1972. The JFCS continued to give relief to the needy and assist refugees in resettling, but also expanded into the field of family and child welfare. The JFCS created the “Denver Plan,” procedures for integrating new residents into the community, which was copied by cities across the United States. The agency hired trained staff to provide service in three areas: family, child, and vocational guidance; service to established residents; and immigrant aid. The agency also handled German reparation money through the Utility Workshop, headed by Mary (Mrs. Sidney) Jacobs. The Utility Workshop produced jobs and services for individuals suffering from emotional or physical handicaps. The services provided by the JFCS continue on through its successor, the Jewish Family Service of Colorado.

Series 1 of 4 contains correspondence from publications, publications featuring photographs created by Marshall Brooks and promotional pamphlets and programs pertaining to the Lamont School of Music’s Dance Department. This series is broken into two categories: The first category mostly contains publication materials of a photography shoot of the dancer Freidann Parker at Red Rocks Amphitheater. There is also a publication featuring Elizabeth Waters doing an interpretive dance in New Mexico. The second category contains promotional materials, music programs and a magazine article all pertaining to The Lamont School of Music’s Dance Department, in which Marshall took photographs of students.

Series 2 of 4 contains letters, questionnaires, and correspondence to and from Carolyn Durand Brooks, Marshall Brook’s wife. Carolyn Durand Brooks was one of the original dancers in the Hanya Holm Company during the years of 1931-1936. All of the material in the series relates to her involvement with the Hanya Holm Company and with Hanya Holm herself.

Series 1 of 6 contains letters and official correspondence concerning the formation and early activities of the National Round Dance Board of Review and the Universal Round Dance Council. The bulk of the material dates between May of 1977 and June of 1978. It is organized chronologically by date. Contents include the original letter asking about forming the organization as well discussions of purpose, draft bylaws, planning documents for the 1978 convention, and financial reports; significant contributors include Frank and Iris Gilbert and Roy and Phyllis Stier.

Series 2 of 6 consists of the newsletters of the Universal Round Dance Council and International Choreographed Ballroom Dance Association. It is made up of physical newsletters dating September 1977 through September 2007 plus digital newsletters on CD continuing forward to August 2012. The CD also includes scans of all prior newsletters except October-December 1977, and scans of convention syllabi from 1977-2012. Newsletters typically include organizational and bylaw updates, convention notices, letters to the editor, welcomes to new members, choreography advice, community announcements, and obituaries. Also included are lists of members on the Board of Directors and the Executive Committee. The bulk of the newsletters were produced by Sue and Bob Riley. The series is arranged chronologically based on year and the numbering pattern established in 1979.

Series 3 of 6 consists primarily of annual convention syllabi produced for the Universal Round Dance Council and International Choreographed Ballroom Dance Association, dating from the first convention. Syllabi are present for 1977-2007 in physical form and 1977-2012 as PDFs on CD (which includes the 1978-2012 newsletters as well). Also included are some ephemera items, mostly daily convention programs, and a newspaper clipping about the 2001 convention in San Jose, CA. Convention syllabi include content such as letters from hosting mayors and the current organization president, committee names and pictures, lists of board members and committee chairs, award notices, top dance lists, biographies with photos of teachers, complete program descriptions and schedules, names of performance groups, vendor lists, clinic workshop notes. Much of each syllabus is devoted to cue sheets for popular dances to be done at the convention. All but one were removed from their original bindings prior to receipt and pages were individually numbered by a previous holder. Of particular note are the syllabus for the first convention, sponsored by the National Carousel Clubs, the advertising flyer for that convention, and a count of registration versus attendance by state from the second convention.
Series 4 of 6 consists of two pin badges for the Universal Round Dance Council matching the design first issued in 1978. Also included is a letter explaining their provenance.

RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: Series 1 contains two papers written by Howard Jenkins during his time at Howard University Law School together with two papers issued by the Division of Social Sciences of Howard University.
Series 2 contains material related to Jenkins work with the National Wage Stabilization Board.
Series 3 contains material related to Jenkins work at the Department of Labor.
Series 4 consists of Reports from the Bureau of Labor Management, including reports, memoranda, correspondence and case studies.
Series 5 covers Jenkins association with the National Labor Relations Board. Included are correspondence, reports, material relating to his nomination and appointment.

Series 6 consists of material pertaining to Jenkins' life after leaving the National Labor Relations Board. Included are speeches and articles, two oral histories with transcripts, and material about the Montgomery County, Maryland Board of Appeals.

Series 7 contains material related to Jenkins' membership in the Cosmos Club, awards and honors he received, material related to his wife and sister and miscellaneous writings that are undated and unattributed.

Series 8 contains publications and notebooks relating to labor issues. Included also are photographs and notebook of a visit to Hawaii as a member of the NLRB where Jenkins was a guest at a review of troops.

RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: Materials related to the building of the Chamberlin Observatory and the Saegmuller telescope: contracts, specifications, bills and receipts, drawings, and observatory account books. This series also includes publications, articles, clippings, announcements and photographs as well as his thesis on Kepler's Problem and several essays and articles written by Howe.

RediscoveryExport.Provenance: Herbert Julian Howe, the grandson of Howe, gifted the diaries in 1998.
RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: Howe's daily diaries recording his personal and work-related activities. The diary for year 1897 is missing from the collection.

RediscoveryExport.Arrang_Organiz: Series 4 is arranged chronologically and by subject.
RediscoveryExport.Provenance: Herbert Julian Howe, the grandson of Howe created and gifted the transcripts in 1998.
RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: Transcripts and history were transcribed and written by Herbert Julian Howe, the grandson of Herbert Alonzo Howe. The transcripts cover the years 1913 to 1926. The histories are ''Pioneer Astronomer: The Story of Herbert Alonzo Howe at the University of Denver'' and ''The Life and Times of Julian Osgood Howe.'' Also included are notes from the diaries and a DNA hair sample of Herbert Julian Howe.

In the class record books, Howe recorded the names of his students and their grades in his classes from 1880-1925. The lesson books cover lesson materials from Howe's studies as a child and lesson outlines for a mathematics course.

RediscoveryExport.Arrang_Organiz: Series 6 is arranged chronologically and by subject.
RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: Howe's personal and family expenses were recorded daily in expense books. Also included is a daily calendar that was given to Howe by DU Chancellor Henry Augustus Buchtel in 1907.
RediscoveryExport.Series_Title: Observation Books, Notes and Reference Materials

RediscoveryExport.Arrang_Organiz: Series 7 is arranged chronologically and by subject.
RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: Observation books contain astronomical observations made at the Chamberlin Observatory from 1897 through 1925, including Halley's Comet in 1910. Observation notes include Howe's notes as well as other astronomers. The reference material is ''A List of Stars for Observations of Latitude with Approximate Zenith Distances for Chamberlin Observatory,'' complied by Charles Joseph Ling.
RediscoveryExport.Series_Title: Observation Books, Notes and Reference Materials

RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: Scrapbooks contain newspaper clippings relating to Howe and the Chamberlin Observatory.

The Inaugural Memoirs series contains 3 memoirs of Mitchell's Inauguration on October 20, 1963. Included are photographs and congratulations from various colleges and universities and appointments of their delegates to the Inaugural Ceremony

RediscoveryExport.Arrang_Organiz: Series 2 is organized alphabetically by subject.

RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: The Office Papers series contains the files of Mitchell when he was Chancellor of the University of Denver. The files include academic departments, subject files, seminars and his resignation.
The Correspondence series consists of correspondence sent and received by Mitchell.
The Speeches series contains materials related to speeches Mitchell gave as Chancellor and as the President of Encyclopedia Britannica Films.

The Newspaper Clipping series consists of clippings about Mitchell's activity as Chancellor, his involvement in DU Theater productions, Colorado Commission on Civil Rights, Community Education Council, and student protests.

RediscoveryExport.Arrang_Organiz: Series 6 is organized by subject and format.
RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: The Photographs series consists of photos of Mitchell including portraits, awards and presentations, events and general, Nigerian visit, office, speeches and theater productions. Also included are photos of Mrs. Maurice Mitchell and her ''First Lady'' Dolls.

The Student Protests series contains materials related to the registrar's office sit-in (4/30/1968), student demands and Woodstock West. The materials have been kept in original order with notes from original file binders from Mitchell's office.
The Scrapbook series consists of materials related to busing issues from 1973 to 1976.
The Kynewisboks series consists of Mitchell's yearbooks while he was Chancellor. Each yearbook has Mitchell's name engraved on the cover.

Series 1 contains Yourgrau's correspondence with various people, both at the University of Denver and throughout the scientific world.
Series 2 consists of letters of recommendation, clippings from newspapers and other publications, evaluations, memorials and memorabilia.

Series 3 consists of documentation on lectures given by Yourgrau. Included are copies of speeches, correspondence with the sponsoring group, transcripts of radio broadcasts, and information on symposiums and congresses in which he participated.

RediscoveryExport.Arrang_Organiz: Series 4 is arranged alphabetically by title or topic.
RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: Series 4 contains drafts and notes related to books and articles published by Yourgrau, either individually or in collaboration with other scientists. Included are fragments or chapters of unnamed publications or on a specific topic.

RediscoveryExport.Arrang_Organiz: Series 5 is arranged by format, then chronologically.
RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: Series 5 contains individual copies and photocopies of individual copies of The Orient, a publication edited by Yourgrau and Arnold Zweig in 1942 and 1943. Also included are two volumes of a compilation of The Orient, published in 1982.

RediscoveryExport.Arrang_Organiz: Series 6 is arranged alphabetically by subject.
RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: Series 6 consists of Yourgrau's notes for teaching various. Mostly undated, the series also contains some pamphlets or publications on the subject matter.

Series 7 contains bibliographies, by subject, of the personal library of Yourgrau. Also included are appraisals and insurance documents for the library, as well as advertisements and correspondence relative to efforts to sell the library.
Series 8 contains publications, reprints and reviews of articles written by Yourgrau.
Series 9 contains photographs of Yourgrau and of his colleagues, slides of his extensive library taken at a time he was offering it for sale, together with drawings and art dedicated to him.

Series 10 contains a grade book, Yourgrau's passport and vaccination record, his appointment as University Lecturer, a plaque with Einstein information and the scissors, gloves and ribbons from the opening of the Yourgrau Centre in Japan.
Series 11 contains 6 seven-inch reel to reel tapes of a series of Lectures given by Karl Popper in 1966.
Series 12 contains two gowns, one cowl and one mortarboard which constituted Yourgrau's regalia.

The Buchtel Family Scrapbook contains photographs of scenery as well as family pictures. The Scrapbook features the family of Frost Craft Buchtel, son of Henry Agustus Buchtel who was Governor of Colorado and Chancellor of the University of Denver. Frost Buchtel was married to Margaret Waugh (1881-1976) whose photo appears in the scrapbook together with her mother and several of her children, including Barbara, Johnnie and Henry Augustus Buchtel III.

RediscoveryExport.Arrang_Organiz: This series is arranged by the intellectual progression of Burton Feldman's research and work. The series begins with general research in to Goethe and Faust. Feldman then wrote a paper on Faust, and began to adapt this research for a larger project on the idea of ''Fame'' in literature.
RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: Series 5 covers the intellectual development of a book that Feldman never managed to get published entitled ''Against Fame: The Romantics and Glory.''

RediscoveryExport.Arrang_Organiz: The series is partially split into individual folders for each author researched by Burton Feldman for ''The Rise of Modern Mythology.'' Other folders are arranged by subject and contents.
RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: Series 6 consists of folders whose content pertains to Feldman's scholarship on the idea of mythology. This research applied to a range of projects including the book he co-authored with Robert Richardson, ''The Rise of Modern Mythology: 1680 - 1860''. The research and notes also apply to a potential sequel to that work, as well as to a paper on mythology that Feldman authored.

RediscoveryExport.Arrang_Organiz: The series is arranged by topic of research as pertains to the various Nobel Prizes or the instituion of the Prize as a whole.
RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: Series 7 contains the research, notes, and manuscripts of Burton Feldman's work on his book ''The Nobel Prize.''

RediscoveryExport.Arrang_Organiz: The series is kept in its original order as much as possible. When necessary, the documents are grouped by subject of research or writing.
RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: Series 8 contains manuscripts, notes, drafts, and research pertaining to Burton Feldman's book ''112 Mercer Street: Einstein, Russell, Godel, Pauli, and the End of Innocence in Science''. Burton Feldman died before the work was finished, and this series also contains work by Katherine Williams and Peggy Feldman as the book was finished and sent to publication.

RediscoveryExport.Arrang_Organiz: This series is organized largely by the individual project. There are sections of notes related to multiple that have been kept together for contextual purposes.
RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: Series 9 contains manuscripts, notes and research pertaining to several novels that Burton Feldman was working on towards the end of his career and life.

RediscoveryExport.Arrang_Organiz: This series is partially arranged, maintaining original order in individual folders where possible.

RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History: Isaac Batchellor was born in 1928 in Lincoln County, Maine. He joined the Navy when he was 17 and served on a man-of-war suppressing the slave trade. While in the Navy he witnessed the revolutions on 1948 in France and Italy. In 1859 he came to Colorado, drawn by Pike's Peak gold fields. In 1872 he married Ellen C. Chatfield. He was a farmer, miner and partnered in a livery stable "Chatfield and Batchellor" with his wife's brother. He was a member of the territorial legislature in 1872 and 1876. He was a County Commissioner for Denver, and Street Commissioner for Leadville in 1881. His last official position was superintendent of irrigation for the State under Governor Routt.
RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History_Biograph._History: Isaac Batchellor was born in 1928 in Lincoln County, Maine. He joined the Navy when he was 17 and served on a man-of-war suppressing the slave trade. While in the Navy he witnessed the revolutions on 1948 in France and Italy. In 1859 he came to Colorado, drawn by Pike's Peak gold fields. In 1872 he married Ellen C. Chatfield. He was a farmer, miner and partnered in a livery stable "Chatfield and Batchellor" with his wife's brother. He was a member of the territorial legislature in 1872 and 1876. He was a County Commissioner for Denver, and Street Commissioner for Leadville in 1881. His last official position was superintendent of irrigation for the State under Governor Routt.
RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: Series 1 contains cards, invitations and newspaper clippings to, from and about Isaac Batchellor.

RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History: Ellen Charlotte Chatfield Batchellor (known familiarly as Nellie) was born in March, 1847 in Mason County, Illinois. She was the fourth child of Levi Tomlinson Chatfield and Lovina Mastick. Her mother died when Ellen was about 11 and she was raised by her brother, Isaac W. Chatfield and his wive Eliza. She married Isaac H. Batchellor on March 13, 1872 in Denver. They had two children, Walter David Batchellor and Charlotte Ellen Batchellor. Ellen died in September 1928 and is buried at Fairmont Cemetery in Denver.

Ellen died in September 1928 and is buried at Fairmont Cemetery in Denver.

RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History: Charlotte Batchellor Sheppard was born December 26, in Arapahoe County, Colorado. She was the daughter of Isaac and Ellen (Nellie) Chatfield Batchellor. She worked at creamery 1900 and was clerk for Tramway Co. in 1903. She married Abel Meade Shepperd, Boulder, Jefferson County, Colorado on May 5, 1920. They had no children. Charlotte died March 22, 1950 and is burreid in Fairmont Cemetery in Denver.

This series contains four documents featuring biographical summaries of the life of Vorontsov. The summaries include a detailed timeline of his life and achievements, and ''Who's Who'' entries. The series also contains two drawings that Vorontsov did as a child.
RediscoveryExport.Series_Title: Overview of the Life of Yuli M. Vorontsov

RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: Series two contains several questionnaires and interviews featuring or related to the life and work of Yuli Vorontsov. There are three transcripts of interviews with Deborah Palmieri, the archive's donor, featuring Aleksandr Illitchev, S. V. Garmonin, and V. I. Churkin. The series also contains two questionnaires created by Deborah Palmieri in order to gather information from people that knew Vorontsov for the ''Yuli M. Vorontsov Memorial Project''. The two questionnaires differ in their approach depending on whether or not they were a business or a diplomatic acquaintence of Vorontsov's. Included in the questionnaire repsonses are the answers of Chestnoy, Garrison, Peyton, and Yanney. The series contains remarks delivered by Vorontsov at the George Washington University regarding the expansion of NATO without Russia's involvement. The series contains two documents obtained from the Telegraph Agency of the Soviet Union (TASS). One is a statment made by Vorontsov regarding Afghanistan in 1988, and the other is an article written about an interview with Vorontsov by the Islamic Republic News Agency. The series also contains a speech made in 1993 by Vorontsov to the UN regarding the Bosnian Croat paramilitary offensive. There is an interview with Vorontsov from 1997 conducted by the Russian newspaper Trud. There are three documents that make up the full text of an interview that Palmieri conducted with Vorontsov gave in 1998. The actual audio of this transcript exists in Series 3. Two more articles, from 2003 and 2007, feature an interviews with Vorontsov that were printed in Russia's ''What the Papers Say''.

Audio digital recording of an interview conducted by Dr. Deborah Palmieri with Yuli M. Vorontsov at the Russian Embassy in 1998. The interview is in two parts. Palmieri asks Vorontsov's opinion on a range of issues regarding the future of Russia. There is a transcript of this interview in Series 2.
RediscoveryExport.Series_Title: Rare Live Interview of Yuli M. Vorontsov

RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: This series contains seven subseries. The series is made up of documents and other resources that Deborah Palmieri assembled while researching Yuli Vorontsov.

This subseries contains copies of four documents pertaining to Yuli Vorontsov. The first is an article entitled ''No Other Ambassador Served in So Many World Capitals'' by V. Shustov that discusses Vorontsov's career. The second is a one page article about Vorontsov and Boris Kolokolov. The third is an article that mentions Vorontsov in a discussion of Afghanistan in 1988. The last is an article that makes mention of Vorontsov a few times in reference to the Nixon Administration.

This subseries contains newspaper articles discussing or pertaining to the life and work of Yuli Vorontsov. There are 120 articles in all, from various publications including The New York Times, the Chicago Tribune, The Moscow News, and the Washington Post.

This subseries contains photos of Yuli Vorontsov collected by Deborah Palmieri. There are 94 photos in all. The photos include scans of physical prints and screen captures of news broadcasts. Two of these photos feature Vorontsov with a ''University of Denver'' banner featured prominently in the back ground. All of the photos in this series are contained on a flash drive that is housed with the collection.
This subseries contains resources pertaining to Yuli Vorontsov that are in Russian.
This subseries contains 63 documents pertaining to Yuli Vorontsov's interactions with the UN. The items are almost entirely documents collected by Deborah Palmieri from the UN Security Council.
This subseries consists of US Goverment documents gathered by Deborah Palmieri that feature or mention Vorontsov's involvement in various diplomatic endeavors.
This subseries contains seven documents gathered by Deborah Palmieri from web sites. The topics vary a great deal, but all touch on Vorontsov in some way.

RediscoveryExport.Arrang_Organiz: This series is arranged into 33 folders. The folder titles are all in Russian.
RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: This series contains documents mostly in Russian and French that pertain to the Museum of Diplomacy.

This series contains letters of tribute to and about Yuli Vorontsov from various people. The letters were written specifically with regard to a farewell luncheon that was taking place. Deborah Palmieri planned the luncheon in Vorontsov's honor. The tributes come from the following individuals: Allen G. Thurman, Ben Nighthorse Campbell, David S. Browning, Deborah A. Palmieri, Dianne Feinstein, Eric Whitman, Frank H. Murkowski, G. William Walster, Joe Twitchell, Kenneth P. McCullough, Marshall D. Shulman, Max Baucus, Raymond S. Colladay, Sidney P. Gilbert, and Wendy G. Burrell.
RediscoveryExport.Series_Title: Tribute Letters to Yuli M. Vorontsov

RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: This series contains four scannned pages from the July - August 1997 edition of Russian Commerce News. The pages detail the Denver Summit of Eight that took place in 1997 at the Denver Museum of Nature and Science. Deborah Palmieri, Yuli Vorontsov, and Boris Yeltsin were all present. The folder also includes a seating layout for the Summit, a list of participants, and a letter from Vorontsov detailing his support of the Conference.
RediscoveryExport.Series_Title: Yuli M. Vorontsov and President Boris Yeltsin Participation in the Denver Summit of Eight, 1997

RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: This series contains scans of nine pieces of correspondence from Yuli Vorontsov and addressed to Deborah Palmieri.

RediscoveryExport.Arrang_Organiz: The 2 scrapbooks in the series are unarranged other than their original order.

RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History:
__ __The University of Denver Arena/Field House complex was home to the University’s athletics programs for nearly five decades, from 1948 through 1997. Most famous for housing the school’s hockey, swimming and basketball programs, the DU Arena and Field House had a proud history.
At the conclusion of World War II, the University needed to expand its athletic facilities to meet the substantial influx in veterans attending the institution. The old Alumni Gym simply would not suffice. DU ended up finding an inexpensive solution that involved veterans, albeit somewhat indirectly. The University was able to acquire a drill hall from Farragut Naval Base in Idaho and moved it to Denver. The federal government had originally ordered the base built almost overnight during World War II. Soon after the end of the war the government decommissioned the base. After disassembling and transporting the structure, the construction teams began to transform the old drill hall into the new home of DU athletics. Three separate structures actually made up the DU Arena and Field House. The South End held classrooms, a track and multi-purpose practice space. The Middle Section contained a state-of-the-art swimming pool. The North Arena eventually housed an ice hockey rink that could be converted into a basketball court. In the basement, there was even an area for a rifle team.
The University was able to do all of this work at a small fraction of the cost for a new building, thanks to the generosity of the federal government.
In 1972, after nearly 25 years of service, the University discovered serious structural problems in both the DU Arena and Field House. Heavy snowfall in December had caused a crack in one of the major roof support beams in the arena. For several months, DU athletic teams had to play in rented spaces, and the University pondered its next move. Did it make more sense to completely rebuild the structure or to safely reinforce it? The administration decided to build a new field house but to repair the old arena The University badly needed a building capable of hosting its large events, both athletic and non-athletic. After a great deal of effort, the University managed to open its athletic complex within just a couple of years. The new remodeled Field House provided more resources for students in physical education programs and additional practice courts for basketball. The unique painting scheme in the renovated ice arena quickly earned the facility a new nickname: the “Rainbow Ballroom.” Most importantly, the University once again had the large assembly space that it required for sporting events and school functions.
By the mid 1990s, the University realized that it was time to upgrade the arena and field house yet again. The “Old Barn” had served DU well for nearly 50 years, but a burning desire to raise all of the school’s athletics programs to the Division I level demanded the construction of a truly modern sports complex. In 1997, the demolition of the DU Arena and Field House began. Today, the Ritchie Center for Sports and Wellness stands on the same site that the arena and field house occupied for nearly 50 years.
Located next to Hilltop Stadium, the Arena and Field House nicely rounded out the athletic venues available to the University. Not only did the varsity teams finally have adequate space, but intramural programs and numerous local sports teams also benefited tremendously from the additional space. The highlight of those early years was capturing five NCAA ice hockey Championships under the guidance of Coach Murray Armstrong. Pioneer athletes finally had the indoor home that they deserved. Although little remains to remind students of the DU Arena and Field House today, many generations of fans will never forget watching the Pioneers in the “Old Barn.” Seats from the arena and bricks from the field house were sold to commemorate past Pioneer glories. The proceeds helped the University raise the funds that it needed to begin a new era in the history of DU athletics with the construction of the Ritchie Center.

RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History:
__ __Dedicated in 1963, the Boettcher Center for Science, Engineering and Research is the oldest building dedicated to science programs on the University of Denver campus today. When it was built, the Boettcher Center stood on the forefront of innovation in science building design. The Boettcher Center is located on the South Side of Campus at 2050 East Iliff Avenue Denver, CO 80208.
From the start of the planning process, DU wanted its new science building to help reconcile the perceived rift in the academic community between theoretical science and applied science. Just as importantly, DU sought to develop a stronger reputation for the study of science and engineering in Denver. This particular emphasis attracted the attention of the Boettcher Foundation. Incorporated in 1937 by Charles Boettcher and his son Claude with the stated purpose of promoting the State of Colorado, the Boettcher Foundation offered the University a grant in the amount of $1.25 million for the construction of a science facility. That donation represented a real precedent because until that time the organization had not really funded major construction projects.
The University broke ground for the new structure in 1961. Housing a mixture of classrooms and offices, a technical library and a large auditorium, the building was eminently adaptable to a wide range of needs.
The original plan for Boettcher called for eight buildings within a complex. Next to it stand two newer additions to DU science facilities, the Seeley G. Mudd Building and Olin Hall. However, Boettcher Center remains an important space for several of the science departments, the School of Engineering and Computer Science as well as the Department of Geography. Though the building clearly stands out today as a prime example of 1960s’ architecture, it is hard not to appreciate the innovation that went into its design at the time of construction. The reflecting pool in the main courtyard not only has aesthetic value: it is also a key part of the building’s coolant system. The Boettcher Center held the first computer on the DU campus. However, even more important than the building itself was its impact on the quality of the science programs at the University.

RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History:
__ __Completed in 1917, Buchtel Chapel was first called the Memorial Chapel in honor of those students who died serving their country during World War I. It was renamed in honor of Chancellor Buchtel in 1949. Sadly, a fire destroyed the chapel in 1983, and only one of the original four towers, Buchtel Tower, stands today. The one remaining tower is located behind Penrose Library at 2150 South Evans Avenue Denver, CO 80208.
Buchtel Chapel (Memorial Chapel) was constructed to provide the University of Denver with a chapel that could hold both large religious and secular assemblies. It seemed fitting to recognize the sacrifices of those DU alumni who died serving their country during the Great War, and a bronze plaque honoring those men who lost their lives proudly adorned the north wall of Memorial Chapel.
The history of Buchtel Chapel began in 1907, when Methodists of the Colorado Conference started to collect funds for its construction. Although the cornerstone was laid just three years later, the chapel was not completed until 1917.
In 1949, the University’s administration decided to rename the Chapel after the Chancellor who had overseen its construction, the great Henry A. Buchtel.
The chapel’s exterior was a fusion of Moorish and Spanish Missionary influences. A tower stood at each of the building’s four corners, each one topped by an impressive copper dome. Despite the Methodist roots of the building, a tablet within the Chapel assured visitors of the ecumenical mission of the University. It reads “In hope that religious prejudices may vanish from the life of all Christian bodies.” The philanthropist who donated the red bricks for the chapel’s exterior and the furnishings for its interior, J.K. Mullen, was a Roman Catholic. The Chapel also held numerous secular events, such as freshman assemblies and prominent guest lecturers. The Music School frequently employed the facility for classes, practice sessions and concerts. Buchtel Chapel was also a favorite for alumni gatherings. During its time on campus, the Chapel was certainly one of the most recognizable and meaningful buildings on campus, a constant through years of tremendous change at the school. Two of the more well known objects owned by the University lived in the chapel: a copy of the Sistine Madonna done by the famous copyist Hermann Till and a donated pipe organ.

RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History:
__ __Chamberlin Observatory is one of the oldest and most well known buildings associated with the University of Denver. Built in 1891, the Observatory is recognized as a National Historic Landmark. The facility continues to serve the needs of DU students as well as those of the surrounding community: the original 20-inch refractor telescope is still functional today. Chamberlin Observatory is located at 2930 East Warren Avenue 80208 east of the main University of Denver campus.
The story of the origins of Chamberlin Observatory is one of personal commitment. Herbert Howe, the University’s first astronomer, knew that his young academic program needed a large telescope. When Humphrey Chamberlin, an amateur astronomer, inquired if Howe would be interested in purchasing a telescope with his financial assistance Howe leapt at the chance. Howe managed to obtain an instrument that cost $11,000, $5,000 coming from Chamberlin. In order to fully protect this new investment, Howe rode with the lens for the entire train journey from Cambridge, Massachusetts to Denver, Colorado.
Although Howe handed over control of the observatory in 1928, he left a legacy of extended and dedicated service for those who have followed. His immediate successor, a professor from the Math Department named Albert Recht, believed that the observatory had an important role to play for the surrounding community: he wanted astronomy to be within the reach of everyone. DU staff member Francis Ohmer became the next man to hold the Astronomer position in 1968, and a strong partnership with the Denver Astronomical Society began to develop. The third Director of the observatory was Professor Edgar Everhart, who gained wide recognition for his research on comets and atomic physics. During his tenure the Observatory received its designation as a National Historic Landmark. For several years after Everhart stepped down in 1985, the position remained vacant. However, a generous $3.75 million donation from benefactor William Womble, who received his BA from DU in 1934, stipulated that DU fund a new Astronomy chair.
One of the West’s most prominent architects, Robert Roeschlaub, had already designed a beautiful Richardsonian-style building to properly house the new telescope. Howe finally realized his dream when the instrument was installed in 1894.
During the summer of 2008, DU launched a major restoration project that will ensure the preservation of the Observatory for another century
The current Astronomer, Robert Stencel, became the first Womble Professor of Astronomy in 1994, and the Observatory had a Director once again. Since taking charge of the observatory, Stencel has worked diligently to preserve it for future generations. First he managed to place the Observatory on the Denver Historic Landmark list. Then he moved quickly to secure a $100,000 emergency grant to stabilize the observatory’s weakened walls and roof. In addition to his impressive work with Chamberlin Observatory, Stencel has also transformed the Astronomy program at DU. He took the lead in the development of the world-class Meyer-Womble Observatory which now sits atop Mount Evans. Chamberlin Observatory still functions today, for both DU students and the surrounding community. Public viewings continue each month weather permitting. It is estimated that 250,000 people have looked through DU telescopes since Howe first introduced the Astronomy program in 1880. This figure would easily make star-gazing one of the favorite pastimes of the DU community.

Chamberlin Observatory is one of the oldest and most well known buildings associated with the University of Denver. Built in 1891, the Observatory is recognized as a National Historic Landmark. The facility continues to serve the needs of DU students as well as those of the surrounding community: the original 20-inch refractor telescope is still functional today. Chamberlin Observatory is located at 2930 East Warren Avenue 80208 east of the main University of Denver campus.
The story of the origins of Chamberlin Observatory is one of personal commitment. Herbert Howe, the University’s first astronomer, knew that his young academic program needed a large telescope. When Humphrey Chamberlin, an amateur astronomer, inquired if Howe would be interested in purchasing a telescope with his financial assistance Howe leapt at the chance. Howe managed to obtain an instrument that cost $11,000, $5,000 coming from Chamberlin. In order to fully protect this new investment, Howe rode with the lens for the entire train journey from Cambridge, Massachusetts to Denver, Colorado.
Although Howe handed over control of the observatory in 1928, he left a legacy of extended and dedicated service for those who have followed. His immediate successor, a professor from the Math Department named Albert Recht, believed that the observatory had an important role to play for the surrounding community: he wanted astronomy to be within the reach of everyone. DU staff member Francis Ohmer became the next man to hold the Astronomer position in 1968, and a strong partnership with the Denver Astronomical Society began to develop. The third Director of the observatory was Professor Edgar Everhart, who gained wide recognition for his research on comets and atomic physics. During his tenure the Observatory received its designation as a National Historic Landmark. For several years after Everhart stepped down in 1985, the position remained vacant. However, a generous $3.75 million donation from benefactor William Womble, who received his BA from DU in 1934, stipulated that DU fund a new Astronomy chair.
One of the West’s most prominent architects, Robert Roeschlaub, had already designed a beautiful Richardsonian-style building to properly house the new telescope. Howe finally realized his dream when the instrument was installed in 1894.
During the summer of 2008, DU launched a major restoration project that will ensure the preservation of the Observatory for another century
The current Astronomer, Robert Stencel, became the first Womble Professor of Astronomy in 1994, and the Observatory had a Director once again. Since taking charge of the observatory, Stencel has worked diligently to preserve it for future generations. First he managed to place the Observatory on the Denver Historic Landmark list. Then he moved quickly to secure a $100,000 emergency grant to stabilize the observatory’s weakened walls and roof. In addition to his impressive work with Chamberlin Observatory, Stencel has also transformed the Astronomy program at DU. He took the lead in the development of the world-class Meyer-Womble Observatory which now sits atop Mount Evans. Chamberlin Observatory still functions today, for both DU students and the surrounding community. Public viewings continue each month weather permitting. It is estimated that 250,000 people have looked through DU telescopes since Howe first introduced the Astronomy program in 1880. This figure would easily make star-gazing one of the favorite pastimes of the DU community.

RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History:
__ __The Daniels College of Business building houses the business programs at the University of Denver. Built in 1999, it stands as a testament to the unique, inspirational vision of its benefactor, Bill Daniels. The Daniel’s College of Business is located at 2101 South University Boulevard, Denver, Colorado 80208.
By the late 1980s, the eighth oldest collegiate business school in the nation needed a new home. After being located downtown for several decades, the program had moved to the College of Business Administration Building (a part of what is now Sturm Hall). However, the legendary philanthropist Bill Daniels wanted to see not only a new building for the business school, but a bold new direction for the program as a whole. According to Built for Learning, “his goal was to create a business school that stressed ethics and values, while also preparing students to become better business and community leaders.” Essentially he wanted to see a curriculum that stressed integrity. In 1995, he provided the University with a grant worth $11 million (after having also donated $11 million several years beforehand) to construct a new building. With the funds in hand (the project ended up costing about $25 million), the challenge became designing the right type of building.
University architect Cabell “Cab” Childress sought ways in which to create the bold environment Daniels had pictured, and also realized that he had to work to integrate this new building into an existing architectural aesthetic.
Located at the eastern gateway to campus, the site for the Daniels College of Business building stood right next to Margery Reed Hall and University Hall, both very distinct in terms of their exterior styling. However, Childress saw Daniels’ request for a two-wing building as an opportunity to establish a unified architectural vision: making each wing correspond with its neighboring building. As a result the northern portion of the building employs modest ornamentation to complement the classic Collegiate Gothic styling of Margery Reed Hall. The southern portion of the college has a roofline that Childress measured to follow the pitch of its counterpart at University Hall. Equally-detailed considerations went into the development of the interior of the building. The materials employed in the construction process, like “Appalachian rift-sawn white oak trim and Welsh quarry floor tiles” were meant to create a warm and welcoming environment.
Another challenge facing Childress and his team involved finding the ideal design for the college’s classrooms: they wanted more than the traditional lecture hall. Inspired by the “case method” approach to business education at the University of Virginia, those in the Daniels administration and faculty wanted classrooms that would facilitate a high degree of interaction between the student and the professor. The result was the “case room,” which Childress designed with a wide center aisle and a more rounded look, allowing a professor to move more easily among the students and to establish eye contact with any student. One of the centerpieces of the Daniels College of Business is Marcus Commons, a pleasant gathering place for business students. It also welcomes those from outside the business school as well: Childress wanted the Daniels building to be an inclusive addition to the University of Denver campus. Perhaps the most impressive feature of the Daniels College of Business building is how it blends the old and the new: built to last for centuries through the use of time-tested construction materials and methods, it also features technological flexibility that allows it to adapt to changing technological needs over time.

RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History:
__ __The William T. Driscoll Student Center at the University of Denver provides the University community with a focal point that meets a variety of needs. With a pedestrian walkway that passes over Evans Avenue to join north and south buildings, the Driscoll Center is also one of the most recognizable structures on campus. The Center serves a wide range of university functions but it remains a student center first and foremost. The William T. Driscoll Student Center is located at 2050 East Evans Ave. 80208.
By the late 1970s it was clear that the University needed a modern student center. The old Student Union building was inadequate did little to attract prospective students. The planning process for a replacement began but initial development was delayed by the controversial issue of funding the project with increased student activity fees. Despite the procedural disputes the University community as a whole understood that DU desperately needed a new student center.
In 1984 DU dedicated the new William T. Driscoll University Center. The unique and modern design was carried out by Denver architect Michael Barber.
The school finally had a building that provided “opportunities for social, recreational, cultural and informal intellectual experiences.” The final plan involved remodeling the old Student Union building to the south, creating a new building to the north and joining them with a pedestrian bridge. The structure provided the University with a wide range of services including student organization offices, an information desk, a recreation center, a ballroom, a bookstore, and a pub. One of the most impressive features of the structure was its internal bridge spanning Evans Avenue. This gave DU students a safer alternative to crossing Evans Avenue than at street level.
It was the All Undergraduate Student Association Senate that had first suggested naming the structure after Dr. William (Bill) Driscoll. A beloved professor, William T. Driscoll served the University for over 30 years. Although he also served as an administrator his true love was working with students, whether teaching or advising. Today, the DU Outstanding Faculty Award is named in his honor.
Today’s William T. Driscoll Student Center still has a bookstore, a general dining area, a set of student offices, and a pub, but all have undergone substantial modifications over the years. Sidelines Pub, Jazzman’s Café and Grill on the Greens were all shaped by student suggestions. The building still acts as the center point of the DU campus. It connects the two sides of campus both practically and aesthetically. Outside organization frequently rent out the Driscoll Ballroom.
