RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History:
__ __Margery Reed Hall, completed over 75 years ago, serves many institutional needs for the University of Denver today, housing a wide variety of classes and the Department of Theatre. Margery Reed is located at 2306 East Evans Avenue Denver, CO 80208.
The only building at the University named after a student, Margery Reed Hall is the manifestation of a mother’s love for her daughter and that daughter’s love for her university. Margery Reed graduated from DU with a degree in English. She earned a position as an Assistant Professor in the same department. It was here that she met her future husband, Paul Mayo, also a DU alumnus and professor. Margery Reed cherished the time that she spent at the University. Tragically, upon returning from a trip to South America Margery Reed died from a disease that she had likely contracted during her travels. Mary Reed, the young woman’s mother, wanted to commemorate her daughter by giving back to the University that had given so much to Margery. Since her daughter had donated to the capital campaign for campus buildings shortly before her death, Mary Reed appropriately followed the same path. Eventually, the generous mother donated over $100,000 to the University to construct the Margery Reed Mayo Memorial Hall. The name would later be shortened to Margery Reed Hall because it was felt that common abbreviations such as Mayo Hall and Memorial Hall did not adequately honor the memory of Margery Reed.
The Collegiate Gothic structure was designed by Charles Z. Klauder, an architect famous for his work on college campuses throughout the nation. A plaque inside Margery Reed Hall explains that the building was dedicated to the memory of Margery Reed and the “Service of Youth in Quest of the Good Life”.
Dedicated in 1929, Margery Reed Hall is now the fourth oldest building at the University Park campus. Although the interior of the building has undergone several changes, it still houses the Little Theater and Department of Theatre, originally called the Department of Dramatic Art. James H. Causey made a generous initial donation that purchased a full set of state-of-the-art equipment for the aspiring theatre program back in the 1920s. The well known Denver artist John E. Thompson decorated the Little Theater with a mural of Shakespearean characters. Lost for decades, an ambitious reclamation and restoration project is slowly bringing life back to this outstanding work of art in Margery Reed Hall. The University Civic Theatre produced several highly-acclaimed plays during the early years, and Margery Reed Hall emerged as one of the centers of drama in the Rocky Mountain region. The building has served other functions as well since then, such as the backdrop for some outdoor commencements. Recently the Daniels College of Business has begun to use the building as the home of its Office of Undergraduate Programs.
The exterior of Margery Reed Hall has a set of stone shields with seven virtues of Christian theology inscribed upon them (Fortitude, Hope, Temperance, Prudence, Justice, Charity and Faith). The statue “Alma Mater” was originally dedicated along with the hall to honor the women Margery and Mary Reed and stood on the central south side of the building. Produced by the noted Denver sculptor Enrico Licari, it shows mother and daughter (or alma mater and student) studying together peacefully. This statue, now resides in the Harper Humanities Gardens

RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History:
__ __Originally constructed to replace Carnegie Library as the main campus library in 1933, the Mary Reed Building has evolved to serve many different uses. What is now called the Mary Reed Building was constructed as the Mary Reed Library as a stone inscription on the front (east side) of the structure still reads. The Mary Reed Building is located at 2199 South University Blvd. Denver, CO 80208.
The Carnegie Library which it replaced was barely 20 years old but already incapable of meeting the University’s growing need for library resources. To find the money needed for the ambitious project the University turned to its most magnanimous benefactress, Mary Reed, who was known as “Denver’s Lady Bountiful.” Having already donated the impressive sum of $200,000 for the construction of the Margery Reed Hall in honor of her daughter, Mary Reed provided an additional $500,000 for the library project and a related endowment A portrait of Mary Reed hangs in the DuPont Room in Mary Reed to commemorate the generosity of one of the University’s most generous benefactresses.
Noted Denver architect Harry J. Manning led the Mary Reed Library design team. The University had decided that it wanted to maintain the same Collegiate Gothic aesthetic that had shaped Margery Reed Hall as they developed the new library. As a result the design team used similar building materials, including rose-colored bricks and Indiana limestone.
A major decision was the placement of the library. Although some wanted to maintain the open view to the west between University Hall and the Iliff School of Theology, the University ultimately chose to follow the Jeffersonian model from the University of Virginia: place the library at the highest and most prominent site on campus. Another feature of the building was its floor plan: an “H” shape allowed natural light to fill the building during the day. The new building provided the University with all of the facilities needed for its central library: space for 400,000 volumes, “spacious reading rooms, customized furniture designed by the building’s architect, numerous exhibit rooms for archaeology and art displays, mullioned bay windows, wrought-iron railings with aluminum caps, exhibit cases, and a distinctive clustering of cathedral lights.” The building was dedicated over three days during the fall of 1932.
The Mary Reed Library would serve as the main campus library for 40 years. By the 1960s however it was already clear that the university needed an even larger library. Penrose Library was built in 1972 as the successor to Mary Reed. The University found that Mary reed was easily adaptable to other uses. Today the building houses many administrative offices such as the Chancellor’s and Provost’s offices and the Honors program. Efforts to modify the building have been kept to a minimum, and the marble floors, Renaissance-style woodwork and Gothic-style windows remain. Recently the University demonstrated its commitment to the future of the building by funding an extensive tuck-pointing project that will replace much of the mortar on the structure Though the exterior of the building looks much as it did in 1932, a great deal has changed around it thanks to campus beautification efforts. The serene Harper Humanities Garden introduced a winding water feature connecting the Mary Reed Building to Evans Chapel.

RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History:
__ __The Robert and Judi Newman Center for the Performing Arts at the University of Denver is one of the finest venues for the performing arts anywhere in Colorado. It serves the needs of the University community by housing the Lamont School of Music and presenting the work of the DU Theatre Department. It also hosts numerous productions from traveling groups. The Robert and Judi Newman Center for Performing Arts is located at 2344 East Iliff Avenue Denver, CO 80208.
The Newman Center represented a breakthrough in the history of the performing arts programs at the University. Completed in 2002, it provided the Lamont School of Music with the magnificent home that its faculty and students had long desired. Founded in 1924, the school had moved from one home to another for decades. Thanks to the bold leadership of Chancellor Daniel Ritchie, the University finally achieved enough financial stability in the 1990s to look towards building a permanent home for the performing arts on the University Park campus. Private donations covered a substantial portion of the construction costs. DU Trustee Robert Newman and his wife Judi stepped forward with a very generous gift that solidified their reputation as proud patrons of the arts and staunch supporters of the University.
As with the Ritchie Center, Chancellor Dan Ritchie and University architect Cabell “Cab” Childress found the proper aesthetic inspiration for the building. Once again they were drawn to European influences: Childress wanted a building reminiscent of “a smooth cup of Viennese coffee in the afternoon.” Childress also worked closely with the Joe Docksey, the Director of the Lamont School of Music, to ensure that the building served the students’ needs above all else. Lastly, Ritchie made sure that those involved in the project were aware of its importance for the City of Denver: he wanted this performing arts center to welcome people from outside of the University community as well. The Newman Center cost approximately $67 million to construct, making it the second most expensive construction project in DU history behind only the Ritchie Center.
The Newman Center actually consists of five distinct structures, each with its own foundation. This allows two inches of acoustic dead space to separate them. As a result each venue can host its own event without disturbing any other part of the Center. Virginia E. Trevorrow Hall is the five-story home of the Lamont School of Music. Containing technologically-advanced classrooms, state-of-the-art practice spaces, a digital recording studio and an extensive music library, Trevorrow Hall serves all of the academic needs of the music school. It also has the distinction of housing an “All-Steinway School,” meaning that all of its pianos are made by one of the finest piano manufacturer in the world. The centerpiece of the Newman Center is the June Swaner Gates Concert Hall, inspired by Italian opera houses. It serves the Denver community’s need for a medium-sized contemporary theater with 1000 seats. Nonetheless, its stage is still large enough to showcase the most ambitious traveling theatrical productions. The design process incorporated Kirkegaard Associates, a group of world-class acousticians, to create one of the most acoustically-advanced facilities in the West. The same company also helped with the construction of the Frederic C. Hamilton Family Recital Hall. Housing a 2,500-pipe Schuke Orgelbau Berlin organ it provides the university with an ideal venue for student recitals. The neighboring Elizabeth Eriksen Byron Theater serves as the home of the DU Theatre Department’s productions. Its unique design offers flexibility with 42 possible arrangements. The Theatre program takes full advantage of this asset employing creative approaches for staging shows. Joy Burns Plaza unites the spaces, housing the Newman Center’s box office. It serves as a gathering place for music students during the day and the lobby for the venues’ audiences during the evening. On the exterior, a massive sundial keeps the time of day on the south side. Figures representing classical and jazz music grace the north side of the building. A beautiful rose window carved into the stone glows on the west side of the building at night.
According to its official mission statement, the “Newman Center for the Performing Arts strives to provide the highest quality performing arts experiences for faculty, students, performers and the Colorado community.”

Lastly, Ritchie made sure that those involved in the project were aware of its importance for the City of Denver: he wanted this performing arts center to welcome people from outside of the University community as well. The Newman Center cost approximately $67 million to construct, making it the second most expensive construction project in DU history behind only the Ritchie Center.
The Newman Center actually consists of five distinct structures, each with its own foundation. This allows two inches of acoustic dead space to separate them. As a result each venue can host its own event without disturbing any other part of the Center. Virginia E. Trevorrow Hall is the five-story home of the Lamont School of Music. Containing technologically-advanced classrooms, state-of-the-art practice spaces, a digital recording studio and an extensive music library, Trevorrow Hall serves all of the academic needs of the music school. It also has the distinction of housing an “All-Steinway School,” meaning that all of its pianos are made by one of the finest piano manufacturer in the world. The centerpiece of the Newman Center is the June Swaner Gates Concert Hall, inspired by Italian opera houses. It serves the Denver community’s need for a medium-sized contemporary theater with 1000 seats. Nonetheless, its stage is still large enough to showcase the most ambitious traveling theatrical productions. The design process incorporated Kirkegaard Associates, a group of world-class acousticians, to create one of the most acoustically-advanced facilities in the West. The same company also helped with the construction of the Frederic C. Hamilton Family Recital Hall. Housing a 2,500-pipe Schuke Orgelbau Berlin organ it provides the university with an ideal venue for student recitals. The neighboring Elizabeth Eriksen Byron Theater serves as the home of the DU Theatre Department’s productions. Its unique design offers flexibility with 42 possible arrangements. The Theatre program takes full advantage of this asset employing creative approaches for staging shows. Joy Burns Plaza unites the spaces, housing the Newman Center’s box office. It serves as a gathering place for music students during the day and the lobby for the venues’ audiences during the evening. On the exterior, a massive sundial keeps the time of day on the south side. Figures representing classical and jazz music grace the north side of the building. A beautiful rose window carved into the stone glows on the west side of the building at night.
According to its official mission statement, the “Newman Center for the Performing Arts strives to provide the highest quality performing arts experiences for faculty, students, performers and the Colorado community.”

RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History:
__ __F. W. Olin Hall is the newest science building at the University of Denver. Built to meet the expanding needs of Chemistry and Biology programs, Olin Hall exemplifies the University’s commitment to both architectural tradition and technological innovation in building design. F.W. Olin Hall is located at 2190 East Iliff Avenue Denver, CO 80208.
Olin Hall represented a major turning point in the history of the University. After coming out of a tumultuous period in the school’s history, Olin Hall was the first construction project that demonstrated the institution’s renewed financial stability in the ensuing decade of the 1990’s. It was the first instructional space built in nearly 30 years. In the early 1990s, DU had begun its ambitious University of Denver Campaign, a capital campaign which aimed to raise enough funding for the construction of a new generation of buildings and for the rejuvenation of on-campus academic programs. One of the first signs of the project’s forthcoming success appeared when the University received a grant from the F. W. Olin Foundation. The only organization dedicated to funding the construction of new buildings at independent colleges and universities, the foundation generously provided the University with over $7 million, enough to build, equip and furnish a state-of-the-art science facility. The administration realized the symbolic significance of the gift as well: the F. W. Olin Foundation only offers grants to institutions that demonstrate financial health and academic promise. DU badly needed the new space considering that undergraduate enrollment in the sciences in the early 1990s had increased very rapidly.
A new science building had been at the top of the administration’s priority list for several years by the time ground was broken in 1995. In 1997 DU finally achieved its goal of providing biology and chemistry students with a truly-modern building.
Olin Hall illustrates the University’s unique fusion of the old and new. The structure was designed in the Collegiate Gothic style, intentionally complementing Mary Reed Building and Margery Reed Hall in the use of brick, granite, limestone and copper. However, the thought that went into the inside of the structure was equally impressive. The Hall houses the expected instructional laboratories, classrooms, lecture halls, offices and greenhouse, though their configurations are on the cutting edge of design. The space is configured to encourage both student-student interaction and student-faculty interaction. It also takes full advantage of the latest in computer connectivity, including interactive learning. With its forward-looking design, Olin Hall can continue to lead the University’s science programs for decades to come.
Since the completion of Olin Hall, the University entered into the most pronounced era of new construction in its history. All of those successors have been built to model Olin Hall’s successful synthesis of tradition and innovation.

RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History:
__ __The Ricks Center houses a school for gifted young children affiliated with the University of Denver School of Education. The Ricks Center is located at 2040 South York Street Denver, CO 80208.
Norma Lu Hafenstein, one of the teachers behind the original summer project that evolved into Ricks, was a doctoral student in gifted education at DU. She believed that the ideal gifted education program addressed “the whole child, including his or her emotional, intellectual, aesthetic, physical and social needs”. That first summer program was a tremendous success, and parents expressed interest in seeing the group’s approach to gifted education integrated into a school’s curriculum. With the implementation of a matching-based admissions process and the help of the DU School of Education, the University Center for Gifted Young Children was official founded in the fall of 1984.
After a prolonged period of renting space from Denver Public Schools and borrowing University classrooms, the school began a fund drive to construct its own building. In 1991, the Ricks Center was dedicated, named after the school’s principal benefactress,
Alta Merle Ricks. Just five years later, a new addition was completed that added 10 more classrooms to the Ricks Center.
Today an early childhood wing houses children as young as three and a middle school wing houses students through eighth grade, both part of expansion efforts. The facility contains a science laboratory, a studio for recording music, an art studio, a technology center, a foreign language laboratory and a multipurpose room (for physical education and theatre classes). The curriculum is tailored to meet the needs of individual students. “The processes of critical thinking, problem finding, problem solving, and evaluating act as an overlay for the various content areas included in the unit topic.” The Ricks Center has established itself as one of the premier gifted education schools in the Rocky Mountain region. The school’s accreditation by the North Central Association Commission on Accreditation and School Improvement in 1997 represented a significant milestone.
Although the Ricks Center is a relatively new addition to the DU campus, it has already demonstrated its value to the University and the larger Denver community. Considering the recent emergence of the Fisher Early Learning Center as a partner for the Ricks Center, the University has demonstrated a real commitment to fostering quality education from a very young age.

RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History:
__ __Completed in 1999, the Daniel L. Ritchie Center for Sports and Wellness is the primary facility for athletic and recreational activity at the University of Denver. The Daniel L. Ritchie Center for Sports and Wellness is located at 2201 East Asbury Avenue Denver, CO 80208.
According to Chancellor Emeritus Daniel Ritchie, the Center was “a dream come true that we weren’t sure would come true.” When he became Chancellor in the late 1980s Ritchie inherited a University with deep financial problems. His exceptional leadership qualities initiated a transformation for the University. Shortly after his arrival, the administration launched the University of Denver Campaign, the most comprehensive fundraising effort it had ever undertaken. One of the major slated projects was a state-of-the-art sports and wellness center. Ritchie noted that everything else about the University was already Division I so he believed that the athletics programs deserved the same. Named in honor of Chancellor Ritchie, the bold building was far and away the most extensive and expensive construction project in school history. In fact, the Ritchie Center promised to be twice as large as the old DU Arena and Field House. Thanks in large part to Ritchie’s energetic fundraising, approximately 90% of the $70 million cost was funded entirely by private donations. The list of those who contributed included some of the most prominent names in Colorado philanthropy. Ritchie convinced these benefactors that they were constructing a building that would truly stand the test of time.
He and lead architect Cabell “Cab” Childress took their aesthetic inspiration from the Mediterranean. Williams Tower, the crown jewel of the Ritchie Center, was actually modeled after a tower at the University of Bologna in Italy. Thanks to the use of quality building materials such as sandstone, limestone and copper, the Ritchie Center is built to last hundreds of years. The Center represented an important part of the university’s commitment to developing the whole person for Ritchie. It also promised to provide the Denver community with a valuable asset, a place where the University community could interact with the public. As the inscription from Thomas Jefferson on the west wall says, “A strong body makes the mind strong.”
The Williams Tower, easily seen from I-25, is perhaps the most widely-recognized University landmark today. Magness Arena is the center point of the Ritchie Center, hosting Pioneer hockey games as well as other Division I sporting competitions, concerts and social events. Hamilton Gymnasium hosts DU basketball, volleyball and gymnastics programs. El Pomar Natatorium, which houses an Olympic-sized pool, serves the needs of the DU swimming and diving programs. The Coors Fitness Center, Joy Burns Arena and the Gates Field House all provide the University with valuable space for varsity practices, club sports events and recreational activities. Significantly, all of these venues also serve the public. Ritchie realized how valuable the Center would be to the surrounding community with its ability to host all kinds of athletic and social occasions. To top it off, the Williams Tower houses a grand concert carillon imported from the Netherlands. With the construction of the Ritchie Center, the university proved that it had entered a new era of financial and athletic prosperity.

RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History:
__ __Science Hall at the University of Denver was the first building dedicated to the study of the sciences at DU. Completed in 1912, the Science Hall continued to serve the University through 1996.
When ground was broken in 1911, only three university buildings stood at the University Park campus, University Hall, Chamberlin Observatory and the Carnegie Library. William McDowell, the University’s second Chancellor, returned for Science Hall’s groundbreaking to celebrate the marvelous growth of the young campus. Chancellor Henry Buchtel had initiated the fundraising effort for the building, and Andrew Carnegie had once again stepped forward for Denver in a most generous way. After the steel magnate had donated $30,000 to build the school’s library, Carnegie kindly offered $50,000 for the construction of the science building. He also gave an additional $5,000 to provide it with the latest in scientific equipment. The total cost was nearly $100,000, with the additional monies coming entirely from Robert Beggs, William Hartman, Charles Crews, William Evans, Charles Hughes and William Pardee.
Now the University had a three-story building with sufficient space to meet the needs of the rapidly-developing science departments. Despite these significant donations, the project did not have a sufficient budget, and the building did not have the same elegant architecture and practical interior design that characterized the other early University buildings. Those who worked in it over the years were not particularly fond of it. Although Chemistry and Physics were the primary early tenants, Science Hall would eventually house Biology as well.
Although the Science Hall clearly needed to be replaced towards the end of its career, its meaning to the early University community should not be forgotten. The old cornerstone from the Science Hall is on display in Olin Hall today. The construction of the Science Hall demonstrated the university’s commitment to scientific inquiry and foreshadowed the eventual emergence of some of the finest science programs in the Rocky Mountain region.
Science Hall served the university well for 85 years, but towards the end of its life it was clear that DU needed a replacement. A great deal had changed in the sciences over that time span. Despite the addition of the Boettcher Center, the Seeley G. Mudd Building and the Space Sciences Research Center (now called the Physics Building), the University lacked the space that it needed for Chemistry and Biology classes. By the 1970s, Glenn Davis, Director of the Physical Plant at the University, received constant requests for renovation work in the Science Hall. The building was inadequate for the needs of modern science departments. The University administration did not have the funds at the time to provide the sciences with a new classroom and laboratory building. Finally, with the success of the University of Denver Campaign, Chancellor Daniel Ritchie found the needed financial support to replace Science Hall. Despite its historical significance, there was no opposition to demolishing the structure: the University needed to move its science programs forward. In the 1990s, enrollment in chemistry and biology programs at the University had risen drastically. With the construction of F.W. Olin Hall in 1997, those departments finally had the state-of-the-art home that they deserved.

RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History:
__ __The Seeley G. Mudd Building is one of three principal buildings for the Departments of Chemistry and Biological Sciences on the University of Denver campus. Its construction in 1982 represented a major step forward for the sciences at DU, which sorely needed a new building. The Seeley G. Mudd Building is located at 2101 East Wesley Avenue Denver, CO 80208.
When the University first broke ground for its new science building, chemistry and biology classes on campus were housed at ten different locations. The University needed a new facility that could handle the programs’ expanding needs. Fortunately the Denver Design capital campaign (a $50 million endeavor) included a new science building as a priority. Two individual foundations were especially generous in their funding for the project: the Boettcher Foundation of Denver and the Seeley G. Mudd Fund of Los Angeles, offering $4 million and $1.5 million respectively. Seeley G. Mudd was a Denver native as well as a renowned scientist and philanthropist. The building would serve as the newest element of a science complex, which included Boettcher Center for Science and Research and the Space Sciences Research Center (now known as the Physics Building). In March of 1982, the University dedicated the Seeley G. Mudd Building, a $6.9 million, 64,000 square-foot investment in the future of its science programs. It was one of the most expensive construction projects in the University’s history up to that point. Linus Pauling, one of a handful of people to have won two Nobel Prizes (Chemistry in 1954 and Peace in 1962), delivered an inspirational address to the excited crowd during the opening ceremonies.
The Seeley G. Mudd Building remains an important facility for DU science programs today. Just as it set a precedent for academic cooperation between chemical and biological inquiry upon its completion, the structure continues to provide them both with classrooms and research laboratories. Although the newer Olin Hall might overshadow its older neighbor in terms of lasting aesthetic value, there is no question about the practical importance of the latter to the development of stronger chemistry and biology programs at DU over the past 25 years.
The DU administration believed that the Seeley G. Mudd Science Building would provide two of its most popular departments with the home that they so dearly needed. Now, with the help of Olin Hall, that same building continues to meet that need in the 21st century.

RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History:
__ __Dedicated in 1979, the Shwayder Art Building is home to the School of Art and Art History (SAAH) at the University of Denver. The Shwayder Art Building is located at 2121 East Asbury Avenue CO, 80208.
The history of arts programs at the university dates back to 1880, when a drawing class was offered. By the 1970’s those programs had expanded enough to need a permanent home of their own. By the time construction began on the Shwayder Art Building in 1977 the School of Art had emerged as one of the most popular schools on campus. However, the program’s facilities were woefully inadequate. Mel Strawn, Director of the School of Art, argued that the state of the buildings was impeding further development of the program. Art classes were spread throughout the campus in eight separate buildings. Several of those structures were prefabricated military huts. Although originally purchased to accommodate a massive influx of students after World War II, in 1977 those “temporary” buildings were still being used for art classes despite the fact that some of them were quite literally falling apart. The University administration had had a modern art facility placed at the top of its new construction list for some time, but only upon the donation of a generous grant in the amount of $1.7 million from the Jesse and Nellie Shwayder Foundation could DU finally begin to make those plans a reality. Jesse Shwayder had founded the Shwayder Trunk Manufacturing Company in Denver soon after the turn of the century, and his small company eventually grew to became the Samonsite Luggage Corporation. Total cost of the project would eventually reach 2.8 million dollars.
The Shwayder Art Building continues to house the School of Art and Art History today. The three-story structure was designed with a high degree of versatility to meet the many needs of the school. It houses all of the school’s art related classes (drawing, ceramics, print-making, sculpture, painting, photography and art history) within a single home. The Victoria H. Myhren Gallery displays noteworthy exhibits, both University and non-University related, that attract a wide audience from throughout the Denver area.

__ __Hilltop Stadium (DU Stadium) stood as one of the most impressive stadiums in the Rocky Mountain area from its dedication in 1926 to its demolition in 1971. It served as the home of the University of Denver football team from 1925 through 1961, when DU dropped football. It also hosted track and field events, other colleges’ football games and even professional football games.
By 1924 DU football needed a new home: the team had been playing at University Park since 1909 with a grandstand that could seat only 10,000. DU alumni decided to launch an ambitious public bond drive. DU broke ground for Hilltop Stadium in March of 1925.
The construction costs ran just under $751,000, with the project using one million board-feet of lumber, 7,000 cubic feet of concrete and 295 tons of steel. The community rallied around the new structure which earned the nickname “Monument to Concrete.” As a crowning touch, the famous sculptor Robert Garrison created two massive figures of athletes, one male and one female, to grace the Stadium’s main entrance as symbols of the value of coeducation and “the vitality, the vigor, and the strength of modern American youth”.
Hilltop Stadium witnessed a wide range of events during its history. Many of DU football’s most glorious victories came on its field. In the venue’s first official game, DU defeated Colorado School of Mines by a score of 27-7. However, no regional match-up overshadowed the annual rivalry game between DU and the University of Colorado (CU) at Thanksgiving. This tradition came to end when CU joined a different athletic conference in 1948. The Denver Broncos also played at Hilltop Stadium from time to time. The facility also hosted other sports during its history including soccer and track and field. The use of Hilltop Stadium extended beyond the realm of athletic competition as well. For example, Charles Lindbergh visited the Denver landmark during a parade held in his honor. Hilltop Stadium also hosted outdoor theater productions and DU commencement ceremonies for a number of years.
DU decided to demolish Hilltop Stadium in 1971. Although the large saddle-shaped section on the west side was removed, the far smaller section to the east remained for a while longer. The venue had started to crumble, and after the discontinuation of the DU football program in 1961, a costly reconstruction of the main grandstand seemed unwarranted. DU also needed the space for its growing intramural sports program: new plans included ten lighted tennis courts and three regulation-sized playing fields for a wide variety of sports. DU has maintained a tradition of changing the configuration of this space to fit the recreational needs of its students. Today, the Benjamin F. Stapleton, Jr. Tennis Pavilion and the varsity soccer field stand on the site of the old Hilltop Stadium.
RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History_Organiz._History:
Hilltop Stadium (DU Stadium) stood as one of the most impressive stadiums in the Rocky Mountain area from its dedication in 1926 to its demolition in 1971. It served as the home of the University of Denver football team from 1925 through 1961, when DU dropped football. It also hosted track and field events, other colleges’ football games and even professional football games.

RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History: __ __The organization was founded in 1948 by a group of leading librarians and library educators to recognize and encourage scholastic achievement among library and information studies students. The motto, Aliis inserviendo consumor , meaning "Consumed in the service of others" was selected by the founders based on the concept of dedication of librarians and other information professionals to the service of others. Eligibility for membership in Beta Phi Mu is by invitation of the faculty from an American Library Association accredited professional degree program.

RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History:
__ __Delta Sigma Pi is a professional fraternity organized to foster the study of business in universities; to encourage scholarship, social activity and the association of students for their mutual advancement by research and practice; to promote closer affiliation between the commercial world and students of commerce, and to further a higher standard of commercial ethics and culture and the civic and commercial welfare of the community.
Delta Sigma Pi was founded in 1907 at New York University: School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance by Harold Valentine Jacobs, Alexander Frank Makay, Alfred Moysello and Henry Albert Tienken. Today, coast to coast, more than 260 chapters and over 220,000 members support the goals and ideals of the Fraternity.

RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History:
__ __The Nation's Oldest and Most Widely Known Academic Honor Society. Five students at the College of William and Mary founded Phi Beta Kappa in 1776, during the American Revolution. For over two and a quarter centuries, the Society has embraced the principles of freedom of inquiry and liberty of thought and expression. Laptops have replaced quill pens, but these ideas, symbolized on Phi Beta Kappa's distinctive gold key, still lay the foundations of personal freedom, scientific inquiry, liberty of conscience and creative endeavor.
The University of Denver Chapter was chartered in 1940. It celebrates and advocates excellence in the liberal arts and sciences. Its campus chapters invite for induction the most outstanding arts and sciences students at America’s leading colleges and universities. The Society sponsors activities to advance these studies — the humanities, the social sciences, and the natural sciences — in higher education and in society at large.

RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History:
__ __Sigma Pi Sigma exists to honor outstanding scholarship in physics; to encourage interest in physics among students at all levels; to promote an attitude of service of its members towards their fellow students, colleagues, and the public; to provide a fellowship of persons who have excelled in physics. Sigma Pi Sigma’s mission is not completed in the induction ceremony with the recognition of academic accomplishment. In the four dimensions of Honor, Encouragement, Service, and Fellowship, the mission of Sigma Pi Sigma takes a longer view.
Founded in 1921, Sigma Pi Sigma is a member honor society of the Association of College Honor Societies. Our society has some 75,000 historical members. Election to Sigma Pi Sigma is a lifetime membership.

RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History: __ __Tau Beta Pi is the only engineering honor society representing the entire engineering profession. It is the nation's second-oldest honor society, founded at Lehigh University in 1885 to mark in a fitting manner those who have conferred honor upon their Alma Mater by distinguished scholarship and exemplary character as students in engineering, or by their attainments as alumni in the field of engineering, and to foster a spirit of liberal culture in engineering colleges.

RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History: __ __Mortar Board is a national honor society that recognizes college seniors for their achievements in scholarship, leadership, and service. Membership is selective and members are chosen by students currently in Mortar Board. Candidates are chosen according to their current grade point averages, rigor of academic program, leadership, and service. This group also provides opportunities for continued leadership development, promotes service to colleges and universities, and encourages lifelong contributions to the global community.

RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History: __ __Founded in 1909 as Sigma Delta Chi, SPJ promotes the free flow of information vital to a well-informed citizenry through the work of journalists. The Delta Chapter at the University of Denver was the fourth chartered when The Writers Club obtained its charter in 1910. It was always a small organization, and most of the momentum was directed toward the national organization. The records of the University of Denver chapter end in 1924. The national organization has changed its name to Society of Professional Journalists.

RediscoveryExport.Bio_Org_History: __ __Scarab was founded at the University of Denver in 1913 as a Senior Honor Society. The Constitution and By-Laws set forth the purpose as 'To associate together find men of sterling character and proved worth for the benefits which come from such an association and for the purpose of accomplishing collectively those things too large for successful achievement for the individual, including at all times a sincere endeavor and active effort toward the further advancement of the University of Denver. __Scarab was open to men of the Junior and Senior classes in teh Liberal Arts Department and required a minimum of two years in the Liberal Arts Department. The organization was founded by Chancellor Henry Buchtel.

RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: This series includes biographical files for individuals who have an association with the University of Denver and have been influential in either the University community or in their personal lives. These files include published materials, newspaper clippings, articles, photographs, and some employment information (generally restricted from public access).
Series 3 contains representative images of the history of the University of Denver selected by the Curators of Special Collections and Archives for prioritized cataloging and digitization.

RediscoveryExport.Arrang_Organiz: Series 1 is unarranged, in that the notes are treated as individual items.
RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: The Historic Bank Notes Collection consists of an assortment of bank notes, many issued by the Confederate States of America which were found by the Union Army near the end of the Civil War. The Collection also contains the letter from the Treasury Department transferring the notes to the University of Denver with an explanation of the transfer.

RediscoveryExport.Arrang_Organiz: Series 1 is arranged by subject, then chronologically.
RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: Series 1 contains governance documents and minutes of the club and executive committee
Series 2 contains newsletters and publicity materials.

RediscoveryExport.Arrang_Organiz: Series 3 is arranged by report type, then chronologically.
RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: Series 3 contains President's Reports, Treasurer's Reports and Miscellaneous Reports.

RediscoveryExport.Arrang_Organiz: Series 4 is arranged by subject, then chronologically.
RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: Series 4 contains material on various committees and events as well as membership information.
Series 5 contains material related to the Craft Guild of the Women's Faculty Club, including governance documents, minutes, and annual reports.
Series 6 contains scrapbooks documenting the events of the Women's Club, as well as miscellaneous items such as the guest book from the Buchtel Bunglow.

RediscoveryExport.Arrang_Organiz: Series 1 is arranged chronologically by the initial date.
RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: Series 1 contains administrative files from the University of Denver Clarion.
Series 2 contains three copies of the Weekly Peanut, the very first University of Denver paper.
Series 3 contains a bound copy of the first school newspaper for the school year 1891-1892.
Series 4 contains a bound copy of the second school newspaper for the year 1898-1899.
Series 5 contains a complete run of bound Clarions.
Series 6 contains four bound volumes of a weekend supplement to the Clarion.
Series 7 contains various loose Clarions.
Series 8 contains issues of Clarions released during the summer.
Series 9 contains Clarions transferred to microfilm.
Series 10 contains photographs of the Clarion staff.

Series 1 contains information on small protests by students from newspaper clippings on the earliest 1911 protest on a disciplinary action to material and fliers on rallies against the Gulf War in 1991.

Series 2 contains material relating to a sit-in in 1968 which students asserted their right to influence policies, such as whether graduate students were eligible for student office and whether entities such as the CIA and Dow Chemical could recruit on campus. Included are newspaper clippings, student press, and administrative information.

RediscoveryExport.Extent: [Extent]3.5 __[Unit]linear feet __[Note](4 legal document boxes, 1 half letter document box, 1 flat box 15 x 19 x 3 inches)
RediscoveryExport.Extent_Note: [Note](4 legal document boxes, 1 half letter document box, 1 flat box 15 x 19 x 3 inches)
RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: Series 3 contains material relating to the student protest that created a shanty town on the campus called Woodstock West. Included are administration documents, faculty responses, fliers, newspaper clippings and other publications, and a scrapbook of the events.
Material relating to the Records Management program initiated in Special Collections prior to its transfer to Business and Financial Affairs in 2009.
Material relating to collections, both Special Collections and University Archives

RediscoveryExport.Arrang_Organiz: Series 1 is arranged by the titles of the officers of the Iota Chapter.
RediscoveryExport.Provenance: The records were maintained by the Sigma Kappa Sorority, Iota Chapter, until they were transferred to Special Collections and Archives, Penrose Library, in 1993.
RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: Series 1contains handbooks and other materials related to the officers of the Iota Chapter, including President, Vice-Presidents for Pledge Education and Membership, Panhellenic Delegate, Philanthropy Chairman, Registrar, Social Chair and Treasurer.
Series 2 contains the business files of the Iota Chapter, including correspondence, minutes of meetings, pledge manuals and reports.

RediscoveryExport.Arrang_Organiz: Series 3 is arranged by type of rush material.
RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: Series 3 contains materials related to rush activites, including party plans, policies, handouts, reports and photographs
Series 4 includes the Chapter's memorabilia, such as award plaques and trophies, books, videos, and oversized photographs.

This series contains images (photographic prints, film negatives, slides, and digital images) taken of University of Denver intercollegiate athletics and recreation (club sports, intramurals, and youth sports) events and activities. This series was collected and arranged prior to 2007. For additional University of Denver athletics and recreation images, see Working Files (Series 6).

RediscoveryExport.Creator: Unknown
RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: This series was collected and arranged prior to 2007. For additional information on the University of Denver men's basketball program, see Legacy Working Files (Series 4), Publications (Series 5), and Working Files (Series 6).

RediscoveryExport.Creator: Unknown
RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: This series contains records related to the University of Denver men's football program. This series was collected and arranged prior to 2007. For additional information on the University of Denver men's football program, see Publications (Series 5), and Working Files (Series 6).

RediscoveryExport.Series_Title: Athletics and Recreation Audio and Video Recordings

RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: This series contains born digital images taken of University of Denver intercollegiate athletics and recreation (club sports, intramurals, and youth sports) events and activities.

RediscoveryExport.Arrang_Organiz: Series 10 is arranged by subject, then chronologically.
RediscoveryExport.Scope-Content: Series 10 contains records of the hocky program, including correspondence, working documents, form letters and memorabilia
